title: US and Dominican import scheme "still failing"
text:
Font size Email Print 
The Earned Import Allowance Program (EIAP), designed to boost US imports of apparel from the Dominican Republic, is continuing to fail six years after implementation, according to an annual review. 
The US International Trade Commission's (USITC) sixth annual report said the programme is not providing enough incentives to help reverse the decline in Dominican apparel exports to the US market, as intended. 
The EIAP allows apparel manufacturers in the Dominican Republic who use US fabric to produce certain apparel to earn a credit that can be used to ship eligible apparel made with non-US-produced fabric into the US duty free. 
However, the report noted that, of the 13 registered firms, only five are currently using the programme, the same number reported in last year's review. 
In 2014, US imports of woven cotton bottoms from the Dominican Republic totalled less than 8% of the value and quantity of imports under the programme in 2010, the first full year of the programme. 
Additionally, US exports to the Dominican Republic of cotton fabrics of a weight suitable for making bottoms fell for the third year in a row, declining by 12% by quantity and 19% by value between 2013 and 2014. 
The USITC said industry recommendations for improvements to the EIAP remain virtually the same as those given during the previous five annual reviews. These include: lowering the 2-for-1 ratio of US to foreign fabric to a 1-for-1 ratio; expanding the programme coverage to enable other types of fabrics and apparel items to be included in the EIAP; and eliminating the requirement that dyeing and finishing of eligible fabrics occur in the US.
